title: A
package.json
c

c

c

c
instead of
--save
c

title: The unique name of your package and should be down in lowercase. This property is required and your package will not install without it.

inline_content.Text: The unique name of your package and should be down in lowercase. This property is required and your package will not install without it.

title: The name must be less than or equal to 214 characters.

inline_content.Text: The name must be less than or equal to 214 characters.

title: The name can’t start with a dot or an underscore.

inline_content.Text: The name can’t start with a dot or an underscore.

title: New packages must not have uppercase letters in the name.

inline_content.Text: New packages must not have uppercase letters in the name.

title: The description of the project. Try to keep it short and concise.

title: An object which is used to expose binary scripts from your package. The object assumes that the key is the name of the binary script and the value a relative path to the script.

inline_content.Text: An object which is used to expose binary scripts from your package. The object assumes that the key is the name of the binary script and the value a relative path to the script.

title: This property is used by packages that contain a CLI (command line interface).

title: A object which exposes additional npm commands. The object assumes that the key is the npm command and the value is the script path. These scripts can get executed when you run
npm run {command name}
c
or
npm run-script {command name}
c

title: Packages that contain a command line interface and are installed locally can be called without a relative path. So instead of calling

c
you can directly call
mocha

c

title: It’s highly advised that requiring the main file does not generate any side affects. For instance, requiring the main file should not start up a HTTP server or connect to a database. Instead, you should create something like
exports.init = function () {...}
c
in your main script.

title: An array of keywords which describe your package. These will help people find your package.

title: These are the dependencies that are only intended for development and testing of your module. The dependencies will be installed automatically unless the
NODE_ENV=production
c

npm install --dev

moment-timezone

c

c

title: A property that indicates that this page prefers to be installed globally using
npm install -g {module-name}
c
. This property is used by packages that contain a CLI (command line interface).

title: The publishConfig is an object with configuration values that will be used for publishing modules. The configuration values that are set override your default npm configuration.

inline_content.Text: The publishConfig is an object with configuration values that will be used for publishing modules. The configuration values that are set override your default npm configuration.

title: The most common use of the
publishConfig
c

is to publish your package to a private npm registry so you still have the benefits of npm but for private packages. This is done by simply setting URL of your private npm as value for the registry key.

inline_content.Text: The most common use of the

is to publish your package to a private npm registry so you still have the benefits of npm but for private packages. This is done by simply setting URL of your private npm as value for the registry key.

title: This is an array of all the files to include in the published package. Either a file path or folder path can be used. All the contents of a folder path will be included. This reduces the total size of your package by only including the correct files to be distributed. This field works in conjunction with a
.npmignore
c
rules file.
